description: Mac Integration Basics is an excellent starting point for people working with Macintosh systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. Viewers who pass the Mac Integration Basics exam will be awarded the Apple Certified Associate certification.
name: Mac Integration Basics 10.11
subtitle: El Capitan 10.11

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Don give a general overview of what you can expect in the upcoming episodes. They cover what the show's about, the target audience, what will be covered overall, and other topics.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.098 --> 00:00:04.626
[SOUND]

2
00:00:04.626 --> 00:00:09.524
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:09.524 --> 00:00:12.888
In this segment, we're gonna give
you an overview of the upcoming

4
00:00:12.888 --> 00:00:16.553
Mac Integration Basic series that we
have coming up here on ITProTV, and

5
00:00:16.553 --> 00:00:17.810
joining me here is Don.

6
00:00:17.810 --> 00:00:21.517
And Don, we have a few questions we're
gonna ask you maybe give you some answers

7
00:00:21.517 --> 00:00:23.747
here about this upcoming and
exciting series.

8
00:00:23.747 --> 00:00:27.361
[LAUGH] The first one is, generally, what
are we going to experience when it comes

9
00:00:27.361 --> 00:00:31.190
to Mac Integration Basics, what does
that mean, what can we expect to see?

10
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:34.460
>> All right, well, Mac Integration Basics
is one of the two exams that you can take

11
00:00:34.460 --> 00:00:36.130
to get the Apple Certified Associate, or

12
00:00:36.130 --> 00:00:38.620
ACA certification,
you only gotta pass one of them.

13
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:39.260
You get to pick.

14
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:41.070
This is just one of those two.

15
00:00:41.070 --> 00:00:43.030
The other one is Mac Management Basics.

16
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:47.870
Now, Mac Management Basics focuses
strictly on managing Macs, thus the name.

17
00:00:47.870 --> 00:00:50.690
Versus this one, Mac Integration Basics,
which actually focuses more

18
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:53.640
on getting your Macs to play
well with Windows machines.

19
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:54.740
I know what you're saying.

20
00:00:54.740 --> 00:00:55.870
What do I care about Windows, right?

21
00:00:55.870 --> 00:00:59.550
But in the business world,
you're gonna find where most environments

22
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.240
are not 100% Mac, or
even 100% Windows anymore.

23
00:01:03.240 --> 00:01:06.650
Now you oftentimes have environments
where you've got a mixture of the two.

24
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:10.120
And getting them to play nice is kind
of an important step that we have to go

25
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:11.590
through to get these things communicating.

26
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:15.630
So what we find is that,
if you work for a company,

27
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:20.150
if you're an IT administrator and
you're tasked with supporting Macs on your

28
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.590
network, you need to have a knowledge
of some of those functions,

29
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.160
how these things work and Mac
Integration Basics is what covers that.

30
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:29.920
>> Yeah, Don, you actually started
hinting at my next questions,

31
00:01:29.920 --> 00:01:32.870
which is, who is this series intended for?

32
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:36.070
>> Yeah, it's really going to be
those IT administrators right?

33
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:39.730
So, if you're a home user and you've got
a couple of Mac's, this is not for you.

34
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:43.897
If you've got a, let's say you work for
a company that's 100% Mac based, well,

35
00:01:43.897 --> 00:01:45.210
again, this one's not for

36
00:01:45.210 --> 00:01:49.080
you cause we're gonna show you how
to integrate systems you don't have.

37
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:52.150
So for you to jump over to Mac Management
Basics, that's a better one for you, cause

38
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:56.110
you learn all the different ways to manage
your Macs and there's really cool stuff.

39
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:58.620
But if you've got that mix,
if you're an IT administrator and

40
00:01:58.620 --> 00:02:01.130
you're responsible for Windows and
Mac, this is the show for

41
00:02:01.130 --> 00:02:03.040
you cause we show how to
mix those two together.

42
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:05.600
>> All right, now that we know
what the show's gonna be about,

43
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:07.625
generally, and who it's for.

44
00:02:07.625 --> 00:02:11.900
Wet our appetites just a bit and
give us some topic details,

45
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:14.040
some of the things that we're
gonna see in the series.

46
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:14.651
>> Sure.

47
00:02:14.651 --> 00:02:17.860
So, I've got an exam outlined here
that we'll be using to guide the show.

48
00:02:17.860 --> 00:02:19.292
Let me just bring this
up here on the screen.

49
00:02:19.292 --> 00:02:21.750
And basically we're gonna start off
talking about network accounts, right?

50
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:24.670
Where are user accounts exist because
you've got like active directory,

51
00:02:24.670 --> 00:02:25.800
an open directory, and all that stuff.

52
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:27.285
So we're kind of start off with those.

53
00:02:27.285 --> 00:02:29.000
We'll talking about file sharing and

54
00:02:29.000 --> 00:02:32.400
how to get files to transfer over
the network between Windows and Macs.

55
00:02:32.400 --> 00:02:35.320
And then we'll take a look at email,
calendars, and contacts so

56
00:02:35.320 --> 00:02:37.130
I like to call it collaboration software.

57
00:02:37.130 --> 00:02:40.920
Ways that we can communicate where
your clients might be Macs but

58
00:02:40.920 --> 00:02:44.230
your servers might be Windows based and
you've got to handle that too.

59
00:02:44.230 --> 00:02:46.010
We'll also take a look at security.

60
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:49.930
There are a ton of security
features inside of Mac OS and

61
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:51.530
they all help protect you.

62
00:02:51.530 --> 00:02:53.900
But some of them get in the way
of you communicating with other

63
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:54.600
machines on the network.

64
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:56.710
So we've gotta understand what
each of those systems do and

65
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:59.100
figure out how to get
that configured properly.

66
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:00.410
Then we take a look at printing.

67
00:03:00.410 --> 00:03:02.870
Printing is less important
these days than it used to be.

68
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:05.050
But many,
many environments still have printers.

69
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:08.460
So we've gotta be able to connect
to those and manage that system.

70
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:10.830
And then,
we take a look at instant messaging.

71
00:03:10.830 --> 00:03:11.540
Right?

72
00:03:11.540 --> 00:03:14.680
This is the messenger
app inside of Mac OS.

73
00:03:14.680 --> 00:03:17.560
A lot of people use it with iTunes and
iCloud.

74
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:21.050
But, you can actually use
it non Mac chat servers.

75
00:03:21.050 --> 00:03:23.510
So, we'll see a chance to work with that.

76
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:26.390
Lastly, we get to see
what's really important.

77
00:03:26.390 --> 00:03:27.710
Data management and back up.

78
00:03:27.710 --> 00:03:29.120
Right?
Protecting our data and

79
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:30.300
being able to restore it.

80
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:32.910
And cross platform compatibility.

81
00:03:32.910 --> 00:03:37.720
It might not be that I have a Mac and
a Windows machine, it might be that I have

82
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:41.788
one machine that I need to do both,
run Mac and Windows applications.

83
00:03:41.788 --> 00:03:43.990
So, we talk about a few
different ways to do that and

84
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:48.270
some really neat infrastructure that helps
you transition from one over to the other.

85
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:48.790
>> All right, Don.

86
00:03:48.790 --> 00:03:50.640
So now that we have some
more of the detail.

87
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:54.170
We have some more of the basic
overview of what we're looking at,

88
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:57.060
you did mention an exam, and
I'm guessing that most of the good

89
00:03:57.060 --> 00:04:00.170
people that are gonna be watching this
are gonna want to take that exam.

90
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:01.340
Give us some of the details on that.

91
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:03.940
What can I do?
I want to get signed up and take it.

92
00:04:03.940 --> 00:04:04.680
What do I got to do?

93
00:04:04.680 --> 00:04:05.910
>> This is one of the nice ones.

94
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:07.480
If you want to get your ACA,

95
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:09.780
you don't have to go to some
special testing center somewhere.

96
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:10.940
You don't have to go to Apple.

97
00:04:10.940 --> 00:04:12.960
You can actually take it from
the comfort of your own home.

98
00:04:12.960 --> 00:04:16.750
You could just go right over to Apple's
website and sign up for the exam and

99
00:04:16.750 --> 00:04:18.440
take it tonight, if you want.

100
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:19.210
It's really nice.

101
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:20.400
And it's pretty inexpensive too.

102
00:04:20.400 --> 00:04:23.260
It's $65, which is a lot
less than a lot of the other

103
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:24.730
certification exams that are out there.

104
00:04:24.730 --> 00:04:27.960
I've got the details kind of
pulled up here from their website.

105
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:33.249
If you go to
training.apple.com/itpro/macinteg,

106
00:04:33.249 --> 00:04:36.670
i-n-t-e-g, /1011 exam.

107
00:04:36.670 --> 00:04:38.210
Right, that's that URL right.

108
00:04:38.210 --> 00:04:38.880
Let me zoom in on that.

109
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:39.750
There we go.

110
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:42.070
So you see that URL, but
if you go to that webpage,

111
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:46.500
they have all the exam information right
there and so you'll see it's $65, you get

112
00:04:46.500 --> 00:04:50.790
two hours to take it, and you can take it
right from the comfort of your own home.

113
00:04:50.790 --> 00:04:54.461
They’ve got the link right
here training.apple.com/acrs.

114
00:04:54.461 --> 00:04:58.490
You can take the exam, as soon as you’re
done you will immediately get a pass or

115
00:04:58.490 --> 00:05:01.460
a fail score so you will know that
you’ve passed, you’re certified.

116
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:02.500
And you're ready to rock.

117
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:03.530
It's all right there.

118
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:06.260
All in all one of the better testing
experiences that are out there.

119
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:07.430
All right, that's basically it.

120
00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:11.980
That is the Mac Integration Basics ACE
in a nutshell and it's a lot of fun.

121
00:05:11.980 --> 00:05:15.220
It's definitely a good time, if you
are that person responsible for Macs and

122
00:05:15.220 --> 00:05:16.830
Windows, this is the place to be.

123
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:18.610
So that sounds exciting.

124
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:19.140
Stay tuned.

125
00:05:19.140 --> 00:05:20.450
These episodes are coming up.

126
00:05:20.450 --> 00:05:24.120
If it doesn't sound too terribly exciting,
if you just work in the Mac only world,

127
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:26.230
then jump over and
check out our Mac Management Basics.

128
00:05:26.230 --> 00:05:27.170
It's already filmed.

129
00:05:27.170 --> 00:05:28.520
It's already in our course library.

130
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:29.680
You can certainly watch that.

131
00:05:29.680 --> 00:05:31.540
And if you wanna learn more
about Windows or Linux,

132
00:05:31.540 --> 00:05:34.190
we've got plenty of other courses
on that in our library too.

133
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:37.592
But for those of you that are sticking
with me from Mac Integration Basics,

134
00:05:37.592 --> 00:05:39.001
well, enough me rambling on.

135
00:05:39.001 --> 00:05:41.393
Let's get this show started.

136
00:05:41.393 --> 00:05:47.834
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain and demonstrate how to connect Mac computers to Directory Services. They start by explaining the concept of Directory Services. Then they show you how to create an OpenDirectory Server and connect a Mac client. Finally, they show you how to connect a Mac client to a Windows Active Directory Domain server.
episodes.title: Directory Servers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain file sharing while using a Mac client in a mixed environment. They begin by explaining the two ways in which you will commonly share files; connecting to a network file server and personal file sharing. They describe the different protocols used when connecting a network file share and then demonstrate those connections. Finally, they demonstrate setting up personal file sharing from your Mac.
episodes.title: File Sharing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore the collaboration software available to you in Mac OS X. Here they show you how to connect your Mac to a variety of different email services such as iCloud, Microsoft Exchange, or even AOL. They also show you connecting to other services that provide contacts and calendar access from multiple devices.
episodes.title: Collaboration Software

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don demonstrate some of the great security features that are apart of the Mac operating system, so that you can support them inside of your mixed environments. They start by looking at the System Integration Protection(SIP) that "sandboxes" access to the system. Then they show you how to  utilize the Password Assistant to help you create secure passwords. Finally, they explain how to use 2-factor/multi-factor authentication for even greater user security.
episodes.title: Security Features

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue their tour of the Mac OS security features. They start by showing you how to enable the screen locking with password feature. Then they demonstrate how to disable automatic login and finally, they look at drive encryption with FileVault 2.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don finish looking at security features in the Mac OS. They pick back up by showing you how to enable a firmware password which will protect from unauthorized hardware access. Then they explain the importance of using antivirus systems like Sophos AV. Finally they walk you through interacting with the Gatekeeper and the OS X Firewall.
episodes.title: Security Features Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the many different ways to connect your Mac to a printer. They begin with the most simplistic method of connecting via USB. Then they show you how to connect to a network printer using AirPrint as well as directly using TCP/IP. Finally they look at connecting to a shared printer on a Windows system and sharing your printer from your Mac.
episodes.title: Printing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to configure your Mac to allow for instant messaging. They start by demonstrating how to configure chat from Mac to Mac with AOL Instant Messenger, Yahoo, Google, and Bonjour. Then they show you how to setup a chat server using Jabber messaging built-in to the Server App.
episodes.title: Instant Messaging

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don tackle the scenario of migrating a user and their data from a Windows based PC to a Mac. They show you how to use the Migration Assistant that is built-in to El Capitan to automate the process of finding and moving user data over a network connection.
episodes.title: Migrating from Windows

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the importance of backing up your data. They demonstrate backing up using Time Machine to a removable hard drive, or a network share. They also discuss alternative backup solutions that may be useful.
episodes.title: Time Machine

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the challenges of using Windows applications on a Mac. Here they show you a few ways that will help you attain compatibility between the two systems. These workarounds include employing Mac equivalent software, using 3rd-party compatibility tools, and running virtualization software like VMware Fusion.
episodes.title: Running Windows Applications

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don discuss the challenges of using Windows applications with Mac hardware. Here they show you how to get around this problem by utilizing the Boot Camp feature of OS X which allows you to install the Windows operating system along side of Mac OS X. They take you from start to finish of preparing, configuring, installing, and post-install features of Boot Camp.
episodes.title: Boot Camp
